A New York column conductor has recently drawn up a list
schedule, and carry the fame of
of the seven "deadly arts." At the head of the list he places editorial writing. A deadly art he characterizes as "one that is no fun
Hopkins to a very high point. This
is a crucial game.
to be engaged in; one that gives the artist small fame, one that
makes the artist feel 'suppose I do this extremely well, what then ?'"
All along the line—"from president down to coal-stoker," as
John Paul Bart would say—there has been a general lamentation
at the decadence of editorial writing. Even our own campus
Skepticus bewails the fact that the editorials of the NEWS-LETTER
are vapid and tiring. Another art has been lost, it is said. The
art of writing editorials has joined the art of illuminating manuscripts, of firing Wedgwood, of embalming mummies, and of a
thousand other delights of the good old days.
The trouble is that the writer of editorials is an anachronism.
He belongs back in the journalism of Addison and Steele. He is
bound by antiquated rules of style and of choice of subject. In a
time when the "personal note" is all the rage the personality of the
editorial writer is lost by merging with the shadowy personality of
the paper for which he writes. Now and then a William Allen
White rises to a position of influence by breaking every existing
rule of the dying "art." But the average editor is never known by
the public.
Few but devoted maiden ladies and the. staffs of rival papers
read the editorials. When the late Mr. Cobb died one or two newspaper men knew that one of the greatest editorial writers of America had died. The reading public were interested until they discovered that it was not Irvin S. Cobb nor Tyrus R. Cobb and then
they promptly forgot all about the dead editor.
The editorial is a doomed species in the journalistic menagerie.
The column has taken its place. an accordance with the "march of
civilization" the NEWS-LETTER is establishing immediately (or
rather re-establishing) a column. May it be better read than the
editorials.

MILITARISM AND GRASS
Yesterday and Wednesday the military unit of the university
was inspected. \\Thich reminds us of the existence of an interesting paradox on the campus. Editorials are written, the Student
Council pleads, the Dean asks that students will please refrain
from walking on the grass. And then the whole R. 0. T. C. battalion marches officially on that very same grass. Under the "iron
shod" feet of our martially inclined the grass suffers far more than
when a nature-loving, peaceful undergraduate treads the turf gently
and lovingly. We advocate a plot of green grass where a pacifically
intentioned student may crunch the crisp but yielding herbage underfoot to his heart's content.

Felix writes from—
Monte Carlo
Say, old dear, didja ever dream of
bustin' the 1st Natl. Bank of Monty
Carlo? Well, that's what your Uncle
Felix just came near to doing. The
trouble was that he didn't stop and
played on in good old poker style to
give the poor bank a chance, which
was lucky for them. Why, at one
time I held first and second mortgages on the Casino.
It was like being allowed to hold a
gold brick for a second, though, and
then have to give it back. Anyway,
money is the root of all evil and I
didn't wanta be a source of crime.
I was thinking of having the Casino
fixed over for my Riviera residence
and buying a couple of those slick
yachts lying down in the bay in the
moonlight, but gave up the idea to
continue with the Purmews tomorrow
to Switzerland.

HOPKINS TEAMS WIN TWO,
LOSE FOUR, DURING
EASTER HOLIDAYS
Lacrosse Squad Defeats Stevens to
Tune of 9-0. Baseball Team
Wins One, Loses One

Johns Hopkins athletic teams
met with such strong opposition
in their contests during the Easter
Holidays, that they could garner
only two victories out of a possible six. These two bright spots
of the program occurred when
Stevens was smothered in lacrosse, and Randolph-Macon beaten in baseball. Defeats were suffered at the hands of HampdenSidney, in baseball; of the Baltimore Country Club, in tennis; of
Syracuse, in track; and of the Baltimore City College, in scrub lacrosse.
The 9-0 victory'overStevens on
Saturday, April 11, is another
proof of the unusual prowess of
this year's lacrosse team. Its playing was marked by a force and cohesion that points in the direction
of a championship. In fact, Captain Einbach of the visitors, stated
that he thinks the Hopkins team
superior to that oi Navy, and that
the Sailors should be- beaten with
comparative,ease.

Tossers Split Even

Although the lacrosse team s at
present undefeated, the nine has
been victorious only once. Randolph-Macon was hauled into
camp with a 9-2 -score but the
stimulating effect of this was
counteracted by the 9-2 defeat we
received from Hampden-Sidney.
Tennis Loses

The tennis season was started
rather inauspiciously as the team
was defeated by the Baltimore
Country Club on Saturday, April
11. Seven matches to two Hopkins victories were accounted for
by Howard in singles, and the
Goldstein-Wassermann combination in doubles. The result of the
match is hardly a surprise as the
Country Club's team is an exceedingly strong greup containing
many veterans.
The outdoor track season was
also opened on the same day by
a 92-38 point defeat at the hands
of the University of Syracuse.
Johns Hopkins took three first
places, while the visitors gathered
the remaining seven. The Black
and Blue victories were won by
"Ridge" Edwards in the 880 yard
run, Gordon Conning in the 120
yard high hurdles, and "Bob"
Heyn in the pole vault. The final
Syracuse score was caused, to a
great extent, by two famous stars,
Bowman, winner of a second place
in the 1924 Olympics, won the 100
and 220 yard dashes. Gottlieb, the
only conqueror of Nurmi, added
many points to his team's total
by winning all of the distance
events.
Red Eagles Lose

In order to develop material for
the varsity lacrosse team, the Red
Eagles started their season by
playing the Baltimore City College twelve on Wednesday, April
8. Unhappily, the local high school
won by a 3-0 score. There were
many embryonic stars discovered,
however, who should be of valuable service to the University in the

"THE PLAY'S THE THING"
OHN BARRYMORE himself would
J"get
the hook" if he did not
know his cues, or read his lines
as called for by the action of
the play.
Engineers get cues, too—
from the industrial drama of
which they are a part. Like actors, their performance must fit
the action of an economic play.
Thus the reason that the
journals, the societies, the
schools, colleges, teachers, and
well-known public men are
urging engineers to study economics—to learn the nature
and effect of economic laws.
To build the largest generator or the smallest meter, for

example, is not always in itself
a great engineering feat. The
feat consists in having it ready
at a time, a price, and with
such features as the prevailing
economic situation calls for.
In this sense engineers_
and particularly Westinghouse
engineers—must be “practicing
economists". They must follow
closely the “action of the play"
—analyzing fundamental conditions in every field, and
calculating their causes and
probable effects.
All this, so that when a cue is
spoken in factory or home, on
farm or railroad, on the sea or
in the air, they may be ready.

This advertisement is eighth in a vocational series, outlining the fields
for engineering achievement in the Westinghouse organization.
A copy of the entire series will be sent to anyone requesting it.

A New York column conductor has recently drawn up a list
schedule, and carry the fame of
of the seven "deadly arts." At the head of the list he places editorial writing. A deadly art he characterizes as "one that is no fun
Hopkins to a very high point. This
is a crucial game.
to be engaged in; one that gives the artist small fame, one that
makes the artist feel 'suppose I do this extremely well, what then ?'"
All along the line—"from president down to coal-stoker," as
John Paul Bart would say—there has been a general lamentation
at the decadence of editorial writing. Even our own campus
Skepticus bewails the fact that the editorials of the NEWS-LETTER
are vapid and tiring. Another art has been lost, it is said. The
art of writing editorials has joined the art of illuminating manuscripts, of firing Wedgwood, of embalming mummies, and of a
thousand other delights of the good old days.
The trouble is that the writer of editorials is an anachronism.
He belongs back in the journalism of Addison and Steele. He is
bound by antiquated rules of style and of choice of subject. In a
time when the "personal note" is all the rage the personality of the
editorial writer is lost by merging with the shadowy personality of
the paper for which he writes. Now and then a William Allen
White rises to a position of influence by breaking every existing
rule of the dying "art." But the average editor is never known by
the public.
Few but devoted maiden ladies and the. staffs of rival papers
read the editorials. When the late Mr. Cobb died one or two newspaper men knew that one of the greatest editorial writers of America had died. The reading public were interested until they discovered that it was not Irvin S. Cobb nor Tyrus R. Cobb and then
they promptly forgot all about the dead editor.
The editorial is a doomed species in the journalistic menagerie.
The column has taken its place. an accordance with the "march of
civilization" the NEWS-LETTER is establishing immediately (or
rather re-establishing) a column. May it be better read than the
editorials.

MILITARISM AND GRASS
Yesterday and Wednesday the military unit of the university
was inspected. \\Thich reminds us of the existence of an interesting paradox on the campus. Editorials are written, the Student
Council pleads, the Dean asks that students will please refrain
from walking on the grass. And then the whole R. 0. T. C. battalion marches officially on that very same grass. Under the "iron
shod" feet of our martially inclined the grass suffers far more than
when a nature-loving, peaceful undergraduate treads the turf gently
and lovingly. We advocate a plot of green grass where a pacifically
intentioned student may crunch the crisp but yielding herbage underfoot to his heart's content.

the Sailors should be- beaten with

Although the lacrosse team s at
present undefeated, the nine has
been victorious only once. Randolph-Macon was hauled into
camp with a 9-2 -score but the
stimulating effect of this was
counteracted by the 9-2 defeat we
received from Hampden-Sidney.
Tennis Loses

The tennis season was started
rather inauspiciously as the team
was defeated by the Baltimore
Country Club on Saturday, April
11. Seven matches to two Hopkins victories were accounted for
by Howard in singles, and the
Goldstein-Wassermann combination in doubles. The result of the
match is hardly a surprise as the
Country Club's team is an exceedingly strong greup containing
many veterans.
The outdoor track season was
also opened on the same day by
a 92-38 point defeat at the hands
of the University of Syracuse.
Johns Hopkins took three first
places, while the visitors gathered
the remaining seven. The Black
and Blue victories were won by
"Ridge" Edwards in the 880 yard
run, Gordon Conning in the 120
yard high hurdles, and "Bob"
Heyn in the pole vault. The final
Syracuse score was caused, to a
great extent, by two famous stars,
Bowman, winner of a second place
in the 1924 Olympics, won the 100
and 220 yard dashes. Gottlieb, the
only conqueror of Nurmi, added
many points to his team's total
by winning all of the distance
events.

won by a 3-0 score. There were
many embryonic stars discovered,

"THE PLAY'S THE THING"
OHN BARRYMORE himself would
J"get
the hook" if he did not
know his cues, or read his lines
as called for by the action of
the play.
Engineers get cues, too—
from the industrial drama of
which they are a part. Like actors, their performance must fit
the action of an economic play.
Thus the reason that the
journals, the societies, the
schools, colleges, teachers, and
well-known public men are
urging engineers to study economics—to learn the nature
and effect of economic laws.
To build the largest generator or the smallest meter, for

example, is not always in itself
a great engineering feat. The
feat consists in having it ready
at a time, a price, and with
such features as the prevailing
economic situation calls for.
In this sense engineers_
and particularly Westinghouse
engineers—must be “practicing
economists". They must follow
closely the “action of the play"
—analyzing fundamental conditions in every field, and
calculating their causes and
probable effects.
All this, so that when a cue is
spoken in factory or home, on
farm or railroad, on the sea or
in the air, they may be ready.

This advertisement is eighth in a vocational series, outlining the fields
for engineering achievement in the Westinghouse organization.
A copy of the entire series will be sent to anyone requesting it.
